text:
> With machine language, any combination of bytes produced by monkeys would be accepted and run. But with higher level languages, we do appreciate the fact that a compiler is able to detect lexical and grammatical errors. Lots of monkeys will go without bananas, but the remaining programs will have a better chance of being useful. Type checking provides yet another barrier against nonsensical programs. Moreover, whereas in a dynamically typed language, type mismatches would be discovered at runtime, in strongly typed statically checked languages type mismatches are discovered at compile time, eliminating lots of incorrect programs before they have a chance to run.

 if even more errors can be found at runtime, then shouldn't we aim to agument compile time checks by simulating the runtime if we want to be as error free as possible? Isn' this part of the premise of Hazel:

elements.text: With machine language, any combination of bytes produced by monkeys would be accepted and run. But with higher level languages, we do appreciate the fact that a compiler is able to detect lexical and grammatical errors. Lots of monkeys will go without bananas, but the remaining programs will have a better chance of being useful. Type checking provides yet another barrier against nonsensical programs. Moreover, whereas in a dynamically typed language, type mismatches would be discovered at runtime, in strongly typed statically checked languages type mismatches are discovered at compile time, eliminating lots of incorrect programs before they have a chance to run.

if even more errors can be found at runtime, then shouldn't we aim to agument compile time checks by simulating the runtime if we want to be as error free as possible? Isn' this part of the premise of Hazel:

text: Yeah, the line between compile-time and run-time isn't as clear cut as we like to present it, if you consider formal proofs, type systems, static analysis, unit testing (potentially QuickCheck-style), and simulation all as tools for detecting errors.

elements.text: Yeah, the line between compile-time and run-time isn't as clear cut as we like to present it, if you consider formal proofs, type systems, static analysis, unit testing (potentially QuickCheck-style), and simulation all as tools for detecting errors.

text:
SO I'm saying, that

g1 ; f = g2 ; f implies g1 = g2

is the same thing as:

g1 ≠ g1 implies g1 ; f ≠ g2 ; f

elements.text:
SO I'm saying, that

g1 ; f = g2 ; f implies g1 = g2

is the same thing as:

g1 ≠ g1 implies g1 ; f ≠ g2 ; f

text: That's logic!

text:
falsish, truish :: () -> Bool
falsish () = False
truish () = True

u1, u2, u3 :: () -> Int
u1 () = 1
u2 () = 2
u3 () = 3

even :: Int -> Bool

even . u1 = falsish
even . u3 = falsish

-- but

u1 ≠ u3

-- so even is not mono!

elements.text:
falsish, truish :: () -> Bool
falsish () = False
truish () = True

u1, u2, u3 :: () -> Int
u1 () = 1
u2 () = 2
u3 () = 3

even :: Int -> Bool

even . u1 = falsish
even . u3 = falsish

-- but

u1 ≠ u3

-- so even is not mono!

text:
Termonology 101 question.

Where Z, X, Y are objects and g1, g2 and f are morphisms. Then this is a category and that category is a monomorphism.

i'm making sure im 100% on that the term is applied to a Category, and not some sub component of the category (which i suppose would be category?)

elements.text:
Termonology 101 question.

Where Z, X, Y are objects and g1, g2 and f are morphisms. Then this is a category and that category is a monomorphism.

i'm making sure im 100% on that the term is applied to a Category, and not some sub component of the category (which i suppose would be category?)

text: That seems counter to what wikipidea is saying, which is that we refer to the morphism f as the monomorphism.

elements.text: That seems counter to what wikipidea is saying, which is that we refer to the morphism f as the monomorphism.

text: So would we say that f is a monomorphism within this Category?

elements.text: So would we say that f is a monomorphism within this Category?

text: Yes, we'd say that f is a monomorphism (I like "arrow" 'cus easier to say) in a category.

elements.text: Yes, we'd say that f is a monomorphism (I like "arrow" 'cus easier to say) in a category.

text: When we say f is a monomorphism, it means that for any Z, g1, g2, some stuff.

elements.text: When we say f is a monomorphism, it means that for any Z, g1, g2, some stuff.

text: Whole bunch of definitions in category theory have this same feel, but with more moving parts.  Like product <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Product_(category_theory).>

elements.text: Whole bunch of definitions in category theory have this same feel, but with more moving parts.  Like product

text: That's why it's pretty important to get mono and epi down, because it's just the beginning.

elements.text: That's why it's pretty important to get mono and epi down, because it's just the beginning.

text: (A product, in contrast, is an object plus two arrows so that for any Y, f1, f2, there exists a unique arrow with some stuff.)

elements.text: (A product, in contrast, is an object plus two arrows so that for any Y, f1, f2, there exists a unique arrow with some stuff.)

text:
Another aspect that confuses me is that => (see picture below) to me implies a rule. If left is true then right is true. As where what we seem to be saying here is that if g1 = g2 given the composition is the same, then its f is a monomorphism.

To me it would make sense to use AND here and say

f after g1 = f after g2 AND g1 = g2 then f is a monomorphism

Filling in our example able above

even? after unit->1 = even? unit->3 AND unit->1 = unit->3 then even? is a monomprhism
True AND false then even? is a monomporhism
false => even? is a monomorphism

So even? isn't a monomorphsim

elements.text:
Another aspect that confuses me is that => (see picture below) to me implies a rule. If left is true then right is true. As where what we seem to be saying here is that if g1 = g2 given the composition is the same, then its f is a monomorphism.

To me it would make sense to use AND here and say

f after g1 = f after g2 AND g1 = g2 then f is a monomorphism

Filling in our example able above

even? after unit->1 = even? unit->3 AND unit->1 = unit->3 then even? is a monomprhism
True AND false then even? is a monomporhism
false => even? is a monomorphism

So even? isn't a monomorphsim

text: "monomorphism" is a statement about a morphism in a category. the way it is defined, however, is a statement about the category, because you have to know about all the morphisms that compose with f, so we might be examining an arbitrarily large part of the category

elements.text: "monomorphism" is a statement about a morphism in a category. the way it is defined, however, is a statement about the category, because you have to know about all the morphisms that compose with f, so we might be examining an arbitrarily large part of the category

text: So yeah, given a mono f, if you find f . g1 = f . g2, then you can be sure g1 = g2.  Since `even?` isn't mono, given `even? . (unit->1) = even? . (unit->3)` you *cannot* conclude `(unit->1) = (unit->3)`.

elements.text: So yeah, given a mono f, if you find f . g1 = f . g2, then you can be sure g1 = g2.  Since
even?
isn't mono, given
even? . (unit->1) = even? . (unit->3)
you
cannot
conclude
(unit->1) = (unit->3)

text: So if `f` in the diagram is `stringToInt`, it's asking is there a way `s` to map Ints to Strings so that `stringToInt(s(i)) = i` for every int `i`?
